info.description: This is to quickly test the Livingdocs Public API. First create a project on [Livingdocs](edit.livingdocs.io). Then create a API token for that project. Use the token to authorize your requests. You can find out more about Livingdocs [http://livingdocs.io](http://livingdocs.io).
info.title: Livingdocs Service

get.description: Your AccessToken is valid for a single project. This endpoint tells you the details and configuration of this project.

parameters.name: search
parameters.description: Search term to perform a full-text search with. For exact word matches use “, e.g. `search=“Ukulele”`

parameters.name: categories
parameters.description: Comma separated list of category ids for which documents should be found. Categories are concatenated with OR. Example: `sport,fashion`

parameters.name: languages
parameters.description: Comma separated list of languages for which documents should be found. Languages are concatenated with OR. Example: `en,de`

parameters.name: languageGroupId
parameters.description: A GroupId used to fetch all translations of a document Using the ?languages param a document in a specific language can be fetched. Example: `?languageGroupId=47?language=de`

parameters.name: contentTypes
parameters.description: Comma separated list of content-types for which documents should be found. Content types are concatenated with OR. Example: `article,author`

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: Filters which (comma separated) properties are included in the response. Defaults to `systemdata,metadata,content` (no renditions). Use `id` if you only want to retrieve the ids of the published documents. Useful (and faster) if you are fully synchronizing your frontend with the publication events.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: A limit for how much published documents to retrieve. Defaults to 10. Max. 100.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: An offset into the query. Useful when getting more than 100 results (pagination)

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: List Id

parameters.name: reverse
parameters.description: Pass `reverse=false` to get the list in the same order as you see it in the editor. (the default is reverse=true for backwards compatibility reasons)

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: Filters which (comma separated) document properties are included in the response. Defaults to `systemdata,metadata` also accepts `content` (no renditions).

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: A limit for how much documents to resolve for the requested list. Defaults to 100. Max. 100.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Filters the result set and allows searching by list name.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: A limit for how much documents to resolve for the requested list. Defaults to 10. Max. 100.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: An offset into the query. Useful when getting more than 100 results (pagination).

get.summary: Get a Category with all Information
get.description: You need to activate the Categories / Routing Feature in the Project Config in order to query categories.

parameters.name: categoryId
parameters.description: Id of a specific categories as fetched from the /categories endpoint.

parameters.name: inheritMetadata
parameters.description: If set to `true` will inherit (but not overwrite) metadata properties from all parents Inheritance depth is limited to 20.

get.description: You need to activate the Categories / Routing Feature in the Project Config in order to query categories.

get.summary: Get a Single Media Library Entry
get.description: Fetch a Media Library Entries by its `id`

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Id of a Media Library entry

patch.summary: Patch a Single Media Library Entry
patch.description: Patch a Media Library Entries by its `id`

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Id of a Media Library entry

get.description: Fetch multiple Media Library Entries by their `id` or `externalId`

parameters.name: ids
parameters.description: Ids of a Media Library entries

parameters.name: externalIds
parameters.description: Must be unique in combination with systemName

parameters.name: systemName
parameters.description: A string identifiyng the external system where the asset is imported from. It is recommended that you always set this value and it is required if you provide an externalId.

get.summary: Get Incoming Publication References for a Media Library Entry

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: A limit for how much published documents to retrieve. Defaults to 100. Max. 100.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: An offset into the query. Useful when getting more than 100 results (pagination).

get.summary: Get Incoming Media References for a Media Library Entry

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: A limit for how much published documents to retrieve. Defaults to 100. Max. 100.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: An offset into the query. Useful when getting more than 100 results (pagination).

get.summary: Resolve a Path to a Document
get.description: You need to activate the Categories / Routing Feature in the Project Config in order to resolve paths to your documents. Routing is a quite advanced topic and the examples only work with a default configuration. Find more [here](https://docs.livingdocs.io/guides/organisation/routing-system/).

parameters.name: path
parameters.description:
Path to the document.

**Example 1:** A page with a category `/news` can be found with `?path=/news.html`.

**Example 2:** A document with id 10, with category /news and a slug `hello` can be found with `?path=/magazin/hello-10.html`.

get.description:
Menu items can be of three `type`s:
- uri for arbitrary URIs, mainly used for URLs
- path for internal paths, such as when the menu item should link to an article or page
- document is the same as path except it is used when routing is disabled

parameters.name: channelHandle
parameters.description: The handle of the channel for which you want to get the events.

parameters.name: handle
parameters.description: Handle of the menu to retrieve.

post.description: This endpoint allows to provide updates for a document/publication regarding its status in an external delivery system (e.g. page build status in a static site generator). The response is a JSON object including the `reportId`.

parameters.name: documentId
parameters.description: Id of the document

reportId.description: If provided this will update the record, otherwise it will create a new one with a new reportId

get.description: This endpoint is the list equivalent of the previous one. The response is an array of objects with 3 possible top-level properties: systemdata, metadata, content

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: Filters which (comma separated) properties are included in the response. Defaults to `systemdata,metadata,content` (no renditions).

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: A limit for how much published documents to retrieve. Defaults to 100. Max. 100.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: An offset into the query. Useful when getting more than 100 results (pagination)

parameters.name: reverse
parameters.description: Order publications in ascending order instead of the default descending order. This is useful if you want to paginate using a time based filter.

parameters.name: homepage
parameters.description: Return only the document labeled as homepage in the current project.

parameters.name: contentTypes
parameters.description: Comma separated list of content types to use as filter.

parameters.name: documentTypes
parameters.description:
Comma separated list of document types to use as filter.
Can be one of `article`, `page`, `data-record`.

parameters.name: id.gte
parameters.description:
Filter by document id range.

Supported filters: `id.gte`, `id.gt`, `id.lte`, `id.lt`.

The id range filter is useful if you want to export a lot of documents. You can do many requests in parallel against the api, where you filter by the specific ranges.

This query is much more flexible than an offset-based filter and works with millions of documents.

Request 1: `?id.gt=0&id.lte=100`

Request 2: `?id.gt=100&id.lte=200`

Request 3: `?id.gt=200&id.lte=300`

parameters.name: publishedAt.gte
parameters.description:
Filter by publish date range.
Supported filters: `publishedAt.gte`, `publishedAt.gt`, `publishedAt.lte`, `publishedAt.lt`.

Example: To retrieve all publications since a specific timestamp, use `?reverse&publishedAt.gte=2021-05-01T00:00:00.000Z`

get.description: This endpoint is the list equivalent of the previous one. The response is an array of objects with 4 possible top-level properties: systemdata, metadata, content, references

The id range filter is useful if you want to export a lot of documents. You can do many requests in parallel against the api, where you filter by the specific ranges.

This query is much more flexible than an offset-based filter and works with millions of documents.

Request 1: ?id.gt=0&id.lte=100

Example: To retrieve all publications since a specific timestamp, use `?reverse&publishedAt.gte=2021-05-01T00:00:00.000Z`

get.description: Required scope: public-api:read. The response is a JSON object with 4 possible top-level properties: systemdata, metadata, content, renditions

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: Filters which (comma separated) properties are included in the response. Defaults to `systemdata,metadata,content,renditions`.

parameters.name: renditions
parameters.description: A comma-separated list of rendition handles. Example: ?renditions=web,json

get.description: The response is a JSON object with 5 possible top-level properties: systemdata, metadata, content, renditions, references

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: Filters which (comma separated) properties are included in the response.

parameters.name: renditions
parameters.description: A comma-separated list of rendition handles. Example: ?renditions=web,json

get.description: Get Publication Events for the default channel

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Number of events to return. Default: 100. Highest limit: 1000.

parameters.name: reverse
parameters.description: Returns the events in reverse order, starting at the biggest id.

parameters.name: contentTypes
parameters.description: Comma separated list of content types to use as filter.

parameters.name: documentTypes
parameters.description:
Comma separated list of document types to use as filter. 

Can be one of `article`, `page`, `data-record`.

parameters.name: after
parameters.description:
**Deprecated**: Please use `id.gte` instead.

Return matching events after this event id.

parameters.name: id.gte
parameters.description:
Filter by event id range.

**Supported filters**: `id.gte`, `id.gt`, `id.lte`, `id.lt`.

**Example**: To retrieve all events since you’ve fetched the last entry, use `?limit=1000&id.gt=40000`

parameters.name: createdAt.gte
parameters.description:
Filter by event date range.

**Supported filters**: `createdAt.gte`, `createdAt.gt`, `createdAt.lte`, `createdAt.lt`.

**Example**: To retrieve all events since a specific timestamp, use `?limit=1000&createdAt.gte=2021-05-01T00:00:00.000Z`

parameters.name: channelHandle
parameters.description: The handle of the channel for which you want to get the events.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Number of events to return. Default: 100. Highest limit: 1000.

parameters.name: reverse
parameters.description: Returns the events in reverse order, starting at the biggest id.

parameters.name: contentTypes
parameters.description: Comma separated list of content types to use as filter.

parameters.name: documentTypes
parameters.description:
Comma separated list of document types to use as filter. 

Can be one of `article`, `page`, `data-record`.

parameters.name: after
parameters.description:
**Deprecated**: Please use `id.gte` instead.

Return matching events after this event id.

parameters.name: id.gte
parameters.description:
Filter by event id range.

**Supported filters**: `id.gte`, `id.gt`, `id.lte`, `id.lt`.

**Example**: To retrieve all events since you’ve fetched the last entry, use `?limit=1000&id.gt=40000`

parameters.name: createdAt.gte
parameters.description:
Filter by event date range.

**Supported filters**: `createdAt.gte`, `createdAt.gt`, `createdAt.lte`, `createdAt.lt`.

**Example**: To retrieve all events since a specific timestamp, use `?limit=1000&createdAt.gte=2021-05-01T00:00:00.000Z`

parameters.name: limit

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: An offset into the query. Useful when getting more than 100 results (pagination).

get.description: Get Incoming Media References for a Document. Added in: [release-2022-03](https://docs.livingdocs.io/operations/releases/release-2022-03/release-2022-03/)

get.summary: Get Specific Renditions for a Publication
get.description:
**Upcoming Deprecation**

Please note that we’re working on offering a better alternative to the renditions with the `Composition API`.

If you need the HTML for a document you can use the `Composition API` and pass the field `html`.

**Required Server Configuration**

Renditions are only available if configured in the contentType configuration.

parameters.name: renditionHandles
parameters.description: A comma-separated list of renditions handles, e.g. `web,name`.

example.content:
a title

some lead

first paragraph

second

and third one. :)

error.message: Processing of Channel 'app' for document '1' failed. Detailed error message…

get.description:
**Added in:** [release-2022-03](https://docs.livingdocs.io/operations/releases/release-2022-03/release-2022-03/)

**Required scope:** `public-api:write` `public-api:drafts:read`

This endpoint returns the most recent draft version of a document. A token with permission The response is a JSON object with 5 possible top-level properties: 
- systemdata 
- metadata 
- content 
- references 
- renditions (if rendition handles are specified)

parameters.name: renditions
parameters.description: A comma-separated list of rendition handles. Example: `?renditions=web,json`

renditions.content:
a title

some lead

first paragraph

second

and third one. :)

post.description:
When you can upload images to the configured Media Library storage (e.g. AWS S3) yourself it is possible to create Media Library Entries through the API.

This has the advantage that the entris will be included in the response directly in contrast to the importImages endpoint where you only get a job id.

You can also provide a custom id to entries which helps with importing documents where images in the document should be referenced with the correct `mediaId` maybe even before creating the Media Library Entries themselves.

mediaLibraryEntries.description: An array of documents to import. Each entry is an object.

id.description: Custom id (Allowed characters: a-z, A-Z, 0-9, and -). If omitted a random id will be generated.

systemName.description: A string identifiyng the external system where the asset is imported from. It is recommended that you always set this value and it is required if you provide an externalId.

externalId.description: Must be unique in combination with systemName.

id.description: Custom id (Allowed characters: a-z, A-Z, 0-9, and -). If omitted a random id will be generated.

systemName.description: A string identifiyng the external system where the asset is imported from. It is recommended that you always set this value and it is required if you provide an externalId.

externalId.description: Must be unique in combination with systemName.

id.description: Custom id (Allowed characters: a-z, A-Z, 0-9, and -). If omitted a random id will be generated.

systemName.description: A string identifiyng the external system where the asset is imported from. It is recommended that you always set this value and it is required if you provide an externalId.

externalId.description: Must be unique in combination with systemName.

parameters.name: baseUrl
parameters.description: Base url of the delivery host

parameters.name: contentTypes
parameters.description: A comma-separated list of contentTypes to include in the sitemap. Example: `?contentTypes=regular,pages`

parameters.name: entriesPerPage
parameters.description: Optional sitemap entry page size. Default 20000

parameters.name: baseUrl
parameters.description: Base url of the delivery host. `?baseUrl=https://livingdocs.io/`

parameters.name: date
parameters.description: Date for the specific month matching the schema from the sitemap index file. Example: `?date=2021-06` or `?date=2021-06.2`

parameters.name: contentTypes
parameters.description: A comma-separated list of contentTypes to include in the sitemap. Example: `?contentTypes=regular,pages`

parameters.name: entriesPerPage
parameters.description: Optional sitemap entry page size. Default 20000

post.description: The goal of the composition endpoint is to gather all required information to render a document in one endpoint and to work for different rendering strategies (e.g. render from JSON or use the prerendered Html). The composition Api supports rendering Html without any configuration, can preload references in metadata and can return resolved includes as JSON. It offers optimised performance for all those tasks and will replace the RenderPipeline feature. We plan to add additional functionalities like automatic design updates of documents and more to the composition Api in upcoming releases and are open for inputs what we could add.
